member.name: M:NvdaTestingDriver.NvdaDriver.GetNextSpokenMessageAsync(System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task})
member.summary: Gets the next spoken message by NVDA asynchronous.
member.param: The maximum time the method will wait for an NVDA message before raising an exception.

There are occasions when NVDA transmits messages separately, in different packets. This parameter sets the maximum time that NVDA will concatenate new messages received within the return of this method, starting from the arrival of the first message.
The action to execute, which should cause NVDA to return some message, which will be returned by this method.
member.returns: The task that once completed, will contain The NVDA spoken text immediately following the execution of the action.
member.exception: Timeout exceeded when trying to get the next message transmitted by NVDA.

member.name: T:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.BrowseModesSettings
member.summary: Sets the browse mode settings

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.BrowseModesSettings.UseScreenLayout
member.summary: Gets or sets the value which allows you to specify whether content in browse mode should place content such as links and other fields on their own line, or if it should keep them in the flow of text as it is visually shown. If the option is enabled then things will stay as they are visually shown, but if it is disabled then fields will be placed on their own line.
member.value: true if [use screen layout]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.BrowseModesSettings.AutoSayAllOnPageLoad
member.summary: This checkbox toggles the automatic reading of a page after it loads in browse mode. This option is enabled by default.
member.value: true if [automatic say all on page load]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.BrowseModesSettings.AutoPassThroughOnFocusChange
member.summary: This option allows focus mode to be invoked if focus changes. For example, when on a web page, if you press tab and you land on a form, if this option is checked, focus mode will automatically be invoked.
member.value: true if [automatic pass through on focus change]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.BrowseModesSettings.AutoPassThroughOnCaretMove
member.summary: This option, when checked, allows NVDA to enter and leave focus mode when using arrow keys. For example, if arrowing down a web page and you land on an edit box, NVDA will automatically bring you into focus mode. If you arrow out of the edit box, NVDA will put you back in browse mode.
member.value: true if [automatic pass through on caret move]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.BrowseModesSettings.TrapNonCommandGestures
member.summary: Enabled by default, this option allows you to choose if gestures (such as key presses) that do not result in an NVDA command and are not considered to be a command key in general, should be trapped from going through to the document you are currently focused on. As an example, if enabled, if the letter j was pressed, it would be trapped from reaching the document, even though it is not a quick navigation command nor is it likely to be a command in the application itself.
member.value: true if [trap non command gestures]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.BrowseModesSettings.MaxLineLength
member.summary: This field sets the maximum length of a line in browse mode (in characters).
member.value: The maximum length of the line.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.BrowseModesSettings.LinesPerPage
member.summary: This field sets the amount of lines you will move by when pressing page up or page down while in browse mode.
member.value: The maximum length of the line.

member.name: T:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.DocumentFormattingSettings
member.summary: Sets the document formating settings

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.DocumentFormattingSettings.IncludeLayoutTables
member.summary: This option affects how NVDA handles tables used purely for layout purposes. When on, NVDA will treat these as normal tables, reporting them based on Document Formatting Settings and locating them with quick navigation commands. When off, they will not be reported nor found with quick navigation. However, the content of the tables will still be included as normal text. This option is turned off by default.
member.value: true if [include layout tables; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.DocumentFormattingSettings.DetectFormatAfterCursor
member.summary: If enabled, this setting tells NVDA to try and detect all the formatting changes on a line as it reports it, even if doing this may slow down NVDA's performance. By default, NVDA will detect the formatting at the position of the System caret / Review Cursor, and in some instances may detect formatting on the rest of the line, only if it is not going to cause a performance decrease. Enable this option while proof reading documents in applications such as WordPad, where formatting is important.
member.value: true if NVDA should detect format after cursor; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether each time you arrow onto text with a different font, the name of the font should be announced.
member.value: true if you want NVDA to announce the name of the font when it changes; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.InputCompositionSettings
member.summary: Sets the input composition settings. these settings allow you to control how NVDA reports the input of Asian characters, such as with IME or Text Service input methods.
member.remarks: Note that due to the fact that input methods vary greatly by available features and by how they convey information, it will most likely be necessary to configure these options differently for each input method to get the most efficient typing experience.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.InputCompositionSettings.AutoReportAllCandidates
member.summary: This option, which is on by default, allows you to choose whether or not all visible candidates should be reported automatically when a candidate list appears or its page is changed. Having this option on for pictographic input methods such as Chinese New ChangJie or Boshiami is useful, as you can automatically hear all symbols and their numbers and you can choose one right away. However, for phonetic input methods such as Chinese New Phonetic, it may be more useful to turn this option off, as all the symbols will sound the same and you will have to use the arrow keys to navigate the list items individually to gain more information from the character descriptions for each candidate.
member.value: true if NVDA should automatic report all candidates; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.InputCompositionSettings.AnnounceSelectedCandidate
member.summary: This option, which is on by default, allows you to choose whether NVDA should announce the selected candidate when a candidate list appears or when the selection is changed. For input methods where the selection can be changed with the arrow keys (such as Chinese New Phonetic) this is necessary, but for some input methods it may be more efficient typing with this option turned off. Note that even with this option off, the review cursor will still be placed on the selected candidate allowing you to use object navigation / review to manually read this or other candidates.
member.value: true if NVDA should announce selected candidate; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.InputCompositionSettings.AlwaysIncludeShortCharacterDescriptionInCandidateName
member.summary: This option, which is on by default, allows you to choose whether or not NVDA should provide a short description for each character in a candidate, either when it's selected or when it's automatically read when the candidate list appears. Note that for locales such as Chinese, the announcement of extra character descriptions for the selected candidate is not affected by this option. This option may be useful for Korean and Japanese input methods.
member.value: true if NVDA always should include short character description in candidate name; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.InputCompositionSettings.ReportReadingStringChanges
member.summary: Some input methods such as Chinese New Phonetic and New ChangJie have a reading string (sometimes known as a precomposition string). You can choose whether or not NVDA should announce new characters being typed into this reading string with this option. This option is on by default. Note: some older input methods such as Chinese ChangJie may not use the reading string to hold precomposition characters, but instead use the composition string directly. Please see the for configuring reporting of the composition string.
member.value: true if NVDA should report reading string changes; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.InputCompositionSettings.ReportCompositionStringChanges
member.summary: After reading or precomposition data has been combined into a valid pictographic symbol, most input methods place this symbol into a composition string for temporary storage along with other combined symbols before they are finally inserted into the document. This option allows you to choose whether or not NVDA should report new symbols as they appear in the composition string. This option is on by default.
member.value: true if NVDA should report composition string changes; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Toggles the announcement of new content in particular objects such as terminals and the history control in chat programs.
member.value: true if NVDA should report dynamic content changes; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.PresentationSettings.ReportTooltips
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether NVDA should report tool tips as they appear. Many Windows and controls show a small message (or tool tip) when you move the mouse pointer over them, or sometimes when you move the focus to them.
member.value: true if NVDA should report tooltips; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.PresentationSettings.ReportHelpBalloons
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether NVDA should report help balloons as they appear. Help Balloons are like tool tips, but are usually larger in size, and are associated with system events such as a network cable being unplugged, or perhaps to alert you about Windows security issues.
member.value: true if NVDA should report help balloons; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.PresentationSettings.ReportKeyboardShortcuts
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether NVDA should include the shortcut key that is associated with a certain object or control when it is reported. For example the File menu on a menu bar may have a shortcut key of alt+f.
member.value: true if NVDA should report keyboard shortcuts; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.PresentationSettings.ReportObjectPositionInformation
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether you wish to have an object's position (e.g. 1 of 4) reported when moving to the object with the focus or object navigation.
member.value: true if NVDA should report object position information; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.PresentationSettings.GuessObjectPositionInformationWhenUnavailable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether NVDA should announce guess object position information when it is otherwise unavailable for a particular control. When true, NVDA will report position information for more controls such as menus and toolbars, however this information may be slightly inaccurate.
member.value: true if NVDA should report guess object position information when unavailable; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.PresentationSettings.ReportObjectDescriptions
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether NVDA should announce the object description along with objects.
member.value: true if NVDA should report object descriptions; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.SpeechSettings
member.summary: Sets the speech settings

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.SpeechSettings.SayCapForCapitals
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether NVDA should say the word "cap" before any capital letter when spoken as an individual character such as when spelling.
member.value: true if you want to instruct NVDA to say cap for capitals characters before pronounce them; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.SpeechSettings.IncludeUnicodeDescriptions
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether NVDA should include unicode descriptions (useful for emojis).
member.value: true if you want to include unicode emojis descriptions; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.SpeechSettings.PunctuationLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the punctuation level.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.SpeechSettings.UseSpellingFunctionality
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether use spelling functionality iss active Some words consist of only one character, but the pronunciation is different depending on whether the character is being spoken as an individual character (such as when spelling) or a word.For example, in English, "a" is both a letter and a word and is pronounced differently in each case. This option allows the synthesizer to differentiate between these two cases if the synthesizer supports this. Most synthesizers do support it. This option should generally be enabled. However, some Microsoft Speech API synthesizers do not implement this correctly and behave strangely when it is enabled. If you are having problems with the pronunciation of individual characters, try disabling this option.
member.value: true if [use spelling functionality]; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.SpeechSettings.AutoLanguageSwitching
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether NVDA should switch speech synthesizer languages automatically if the text being read specifies its language. This option is enabled by default. Currently only the eSpeak NG synthesizer supports automatic language switching.
member.value: true if you want to enable automatic language switching; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: Currently this settings will have no effect on returned text, but will be implemented in the future.

member.name: P:NvdaTestingDriver.Settings.SpeechSettings.AutoDialectSwitching
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether or not dialect changes should be made, rather than just actual language changes. For example, if reading in an English U.S.voice but a document specifies that some text is in English U.K., then the synthesizer will switch accents if this option is enabled. This option is disabled by default.
member.value: true if you want to enable the automatic dialect switching; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: Currently this settings will have no effect on returned text, but will be implemented in the future.
